title: How can philosophy help me as a person? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi Philip and Readers, It’s not going to help you but it may inspire you in thoughts and ideas. Studying philosophy or life related things can actually create a lot of confusion within you. I experienced that during a period of awakening. It’s quite frustrating because all you wish to know is the truth about who you are, why you are and where you go? But, equally it’s inspiration for your being. Let you inner heart guide you, because it will. Be patient because like a human grows from baby to adult so does the inner spirit of you. It comes when the time is right. You cannot learn life intellectually but through experience and heart you learn a lot. Mind is temporary, Spirit (Source) is permanent. Mind has limitations although they evolve. Spirit has NO limitation because it’s the Source of all. So, ALL answers are within you. Ready for you when you’re ready. Trust yourself and follow your heart intuition. Read that which you feel you shall read. Ponder only that which you feel you should ponder. Answers will come within you. YOU ARE YOUR OWN LAW AND JUDGE. Good luck with your search, Ralph A voice in the Ocean

Learning to like philosophy depends on your motivation to expand your mind and stretch your imagination. Philosophy allows you to think on more than one level at a time. Learning to abstract and analyse and argue from different points of view is a skill. I believe, this skill is good for intellectual and emotional development. The history of Western thought has in roots in Greek Philosophy. Think of the contributions made to our heritage by names like Aristotle, Plato, and Cicero. There are German, British, and American philosophers. William James is one of my favorites. Thinking clearly requires patience and self reflection. Philosophy helps us to reflect on politics, history, ethics, and even the concept of a “Good Life”. John Kekes has taught me how to understand the nature of “Evil”. Martha Nussbaum taught me about empathy in literature and how to define it. There are wonderful philosophical analysis of critical thinkers like Shakespeare and psychologists like Freud. Murdoch and Midgley have written on the philosophy of “The Good” and the definition of “Wickedness” , respectively. Read any books on the history of Western Thought and you will be reading about Philosophy. Religion is a Philosophical problem and many turn to religious thinkers for spiritual guidance. All in all, developing a taste for the classics is a window for penetrating many of the area studied by philosophers as well.

Among other things, philosophy helps you understand exactly what constitutes a good person. As he stated in his public trial in ancient Athens in 399 BC, that was one of Socrates’ primary motivations. Hence, his statement in his trial of “The unexamined life is not worth living.” By understanding what the good life consists of one is able to have a model to aim for — even if we miss it by a little bit then we are not shooting in the dark like most people.

Studying philosophy teaches a person how to think. Picking one philosophy and sticking to it is an option, but its not the one and only strategy available. Picking through as many philosophies as possible to compare and contrast may lead a person to an enlightened view of the world, the universe and most importantly themselves.

You don’t need philosophy to become a better person. In fact there have been quite a few philosophers who have not been all that good. All we need to be a good (better) person is to develop the qualities of kindness, compassion, willingness to help others, a sense of humor, good cheer when with other people, and refrain from anger, hate, and intolerance. Peace! Oct 19 2020

Sound philosophy can instruct your mind as to what is true, and incorporating that knowledge can be helpful. However, a decision is required that you will actually follow what you have discovered to be true! Thus we can decide to actually do what leads to the habits of virtue, and refuse vices! This is not an easy task, but well worth it! The books of William Bennett seem to be a good beginning point!
